title: Using Mendelian randomization to investigate a possible causal relationship between adiposity and increased bone mineral density at different skeletal sites in children
author: Kemp
author_address: University of Queensland Diamantina Institute, Level 5 Translational Research Institute, Woolloongabba, Brisbane 4102, QLD, Australia
hypothesis: Effect of adiposity on bone mineral density
rationale: Lean mass is positively associated with bone mineral density (BMD). However, the relationship between adiposity and BMD is more controversial. In particu- lar, it is unclear if the observational association between the two reflects a causal effect of fat mass on BMD.
outcome_definition: Dual-energy X-ray absoptiometry (DXA) measures of BMD were derived for this region of interest
exposure_n_difference_reason: One-sample where they got exposure SNPs from external GWAS
exposure_covariates_model: Sex and age were included as covariates in order to generate estimates from the IV analyses that were comparable to those from the observational regressions
exposure_genotyping_dataset: Illumina HumanHap550 quad genome-wide SNP genotyping platform
exposure_independence: r²  values for SNPs given in supplementary tables
exposure_HWE: Only SNPs that passed an exact test of Hardy– Weinberg equilibrium (P > 5 x10-7) were considered for analysis
limitations_overall: Findings would benefit from replication in a larger sample of individuals as well as utilizing SNPs that are specific (and strongly associated with) lean or fat mass.
limitations_pleiotropy: Employed two statistical procedures to mitigate concerns due to horizontal pleiotropy: MR Egger regression and multivariable MR.
limitations_population_stratification: EIGENSTRAT analysis revealed no additional obvious population stratification
notes: Used BMI SNPs for fat mass

title:
Using multiple genetic variants


as instrumental variables for


modifiable risk factors
author: Palmer
author_address: MRC Centre for Causal Analyses in Translational Epidemiology United Kingdom
hypothesis: Effect of fat mass on bone mineral density
rationale: Methods paper using body mass index and bone mineral density as example
exposure_study: Willer 2008 Body mass index European both
exposure_n_difference_reason: One sample with SNPs from external GWAS
limitations_overall: Method comparison paper using BMI/bone mineral density as example.

title: How Does Body Fat Influence Bone Mass in Childhood? A Mendelian Randomization Approach
journal: JOURNAL OF BONE AND MINERAL RESEARCH
author: Timpson
author_address: Academic Rheumatology, Avon Orthopaedic Centre, Bristol BS10 5NB
hypothesis: Effect of trunk fat mass on bone mass traits
rationale:
Fat mass may be a causal determinant of bone mass, but the evidence is conflicting, possibly
reflecting the influence of confounding factors
outcome_definition: obtained by dividing BMC by BA
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Genotyped rare FTO and MC4R variants
limitations_pleiotropy:
Pleiotropism, whereby genetic markers affect the outcome of interest independently of the exposure variable (in this instance fat mass), is one of several factors that can complicate interpretation of MR analyses. For example, MC4R is known to be a major regulator of cocaine- and
amphetamine-regulated transcript (CART) in the hypothalamus,
the absence of which in mice leads to a low bone
mass phenotype secondary to increased bone resorption

title: How Does Body Fat Influence Bone Mass in Childhood? A Mendelian Randomization Approach
journal: JOURNAL OF BONE AND MINERAL RESEARCH
author: Timpson
author_address: Academic Rheumatology, Avon Orthopaedic Centre, Bristol BS10 5NB
hypothesis: Effect of trunk fat mass on bone mass traits
rationale:
Fat mass may be a causal determinant of bone mass, but the evidence is conflicting, possibly
reflecting the influence of confounding factors
outcome_definition: DXA variables for the spine were derived from spine subregional analysis of whole body scans, excluding scans showing any spinal curvature. obtained by dividing BMC by BA
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Genotyped rare FTO and MC4R variants
limitations_pleiotropy:
Pleiotropism, whereby genetic markers affect the outcome of interest independently of the exposure variable (in this instance fat mass), is one of several factors that can complicate interpretation of MR analyses. For example, MC4R is known to be a major regulator of cocaine- and
amphetamine-regulated transcript (CART) in the hypothalamus,
the absence of which in mice leads to a low bone
mass phenotype secondary to increased bone resorption
